prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band 3, SiO J=2-1, v=0,1,2,3
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note: Includes all the main SiO lines of this proposal: J=2-1, v=0,1,2,3

prj:VisitConstraint.prj:note: We would ideally like to probe two additional random phases in addition to the one obtained during the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign (SV data). The minimum separation should be 20 days, so that the 2nd phase is different to the first one. The first epoch alone is also already useful as it will alreayd add a 2nd epoch to the SV data.

We would ideally like to probe two additional random phases in addition to the one obtained during the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign (SV data). The minimum separation should be 20 days, so that the 2nd phase is different to the first one. The first epoch alone is also already useful as it will alreayd add a 2nd epoch to the SV data.

prj:TechnicalJustification.prj:justificationText: We would like to reach comparable spectral resolution to the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign SV data (Wittkowski et al, A&A, submitted).
Angular scales are taken from the images obtained from the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign SV data (Wittkowski et al., A&A, submitted).

Flux densities are estimated from the results from tha ALMA Long Baseline Campaign SV data (Wittkowski et al., A&A, submitted). The rms is selected to be comparable to these previous SV observations. We will reach a continuum sensitivity of about 130 micro-Jy, which will allow us to safely detect the continuum emission of Mira A (~23 mJy) and to relate the SiO emission relative to the continuum emission.
See above, spectral resolution needs to be comparable to that of the available SV data for comparison.

We would ideally like to probe two additional random phases in addition to the one obtained during the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign (SV data). The minimum separation should be 20 days, so that the 2nd phase is different to the first one. The first epoch alone is also already useful as it will already add a 2nd epoch to the SV data and further constrain our modeling. A 2nd additional epoch would add more information on the intracycle variability.

Flux densities are estimated from the results from tha ALMA Long Baseline Campaign SV data (Wittkowski et al., A&A, submitted). The rms is selected to be comparable to these previous SV observations. We will reach a continuum sensitivity of about 150 micro-Jy, which will allow us to safely detect the continuum emission of Mira A (~70 mJy) and to relate the SiO emission relative to the continuum emission.
We would like to reach comparable spectral resolution to the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign SV data (Wittkowski et al, A&A, submitted).

We would ideally like to probe two additional random phases in addition to the one obtained during the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign (SV data). The minimum separation should be 20 days, so that the 2nd phase is different to the first one. The first epoch alone is also already useful as it will alreayd add a 2nd epoch to the SV data. A 2nd additional epoch would add more information on the variability.

prj:ScienceGoal.prj:name: Band7, SiO, J=7-6, v=0,1
prj:ScienceGoal.prj:note:
Includes two of the main SiO lines of this proposal: J=7-6, v=0,1
In addition, includes in the available basebands: 30 SiO v=2 J=7-6 and SO (301.286 GHz)

prp:ObsProposal.prp:abstract:
We studied the radial structure and morphology of the SiO emitting regions toward the prototypical Mira variable o Ceti based on Band 3 and Band 6 Science Verification data from the ALMA Long Baseline Campaign obtained at a phase of about 0.4 (submitted to A&A). The vibrationally ground state transitions showed a clumpy shell-like morphology with Gaussian FWHM spatial extensions between about 200 mas to 400 mas, corresponding to about 20-40 AU, overlapping with the dust formation zone. Maser emission was confirmed for the brightest clumps of one v=0 and the v=1 transitions. The data showed central intensity dips, of which some are significantly below the continuum level, indicating absorbing infalling SiO gas.
Here, we propose to add observations at two further phases, as well as v=3 transitions, and Band 7 transitions to enhance our picture of the SiO emitting regions and the shock-driven atmosphere. High-frequency maser emission as well as the inner shock-related outflowing/infalling velocity fields are known to be phase-dependent. Results will be compared to new time-dependent radiative transfer modeling of both thermal and maser emission.
prp:ObsProposal.prp:previousProposals: 2013.1.00402.S, PI Wittkowski: Observations were ranked in the 20-40% bin. However, a part of the proposed observations were then executed as ALMA SV observation and analyzed by our team.
